<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 277, 230, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/42  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 301, 240, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 384, 391, 399]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 650]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.- Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{ms}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 680, 212, 694]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 696, 728, 727]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
1

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 87, 685, 256]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 278, 918, 310]]<|/det|>
Three coplanar forces of magnitudes 40 N , 30 N and \(X \mathrm{~N}\) act at a point in the directions shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 323, 641, 341]]<|/det|>
Given that the forces are in equilibrium, find the values of \(\theta\) and \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 77, 99, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 78, 918, 144]]<|/det|>
2 A cyclist is travelling along a straight horizontal road at a speed of \(4 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) when she passes a point \(O\). She accelerates at a constant rate for a distance of \(42 \mathrm{~m}\), reaching a speed of \(V \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\). She maintains the speed of \(V \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) for \(50 \mathrm{~m}\) and then decelerates at \(2 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\) before coming to rest. The distance travelled while decelerating is \(16 \mathrm{~m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 160, 144, 177]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 158, 314, 176]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the value of \(V\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 498, 144, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 496, 780, 515]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the total time for which she is in motion from the instant that she passes \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 99, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 450, 91]]<|/det|>
3 An aeroplane is flying at a constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 106, 144, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 104, 921, 136]]<|/det|>
(a) The aeroplane is flying horizontally. The aeroplane's engines are producing a constant power of 5500 kW , and the aeroplane experiences a constant horizontal resistance force of 25 kN .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 152, 408, 168]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of the aeroplane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 460, 144, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 459, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
(b) The aeroplane then ascends 300 m in 50 s , while maintaining the same speed. The resistance force is no longer constant, and the work done against the resistance force in ascending the 300 m is 270 000 kJ . The mass of the aeroplane is 60 000 kg .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 521, 554, 538]]<|/det|>
Find the average power of the aeroplane's engines.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
4

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 84, 650, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 272, 918, 335]]<|/det|>
Two particles \(A\) and \(B\) have masses 0.3 kg and 0.1 kg respectively. The particles are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a fixed smooth pulley, and the particles hang vertically below the pulley. Both particles are initially at a height of \(x \mathrm{~m}\) above horizontal ground (see diagram). The system is released from rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 351, 144, 367]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 349, 667, 367]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the tension in the string and the acceleration of the particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
<pre>During the subsequent motion, \(B\) does not reach the pulley. When \(A\) reaches the ground, it comes to rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 121, 144, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 121, 784, 138]]<|/det|>
(b) Given that the greatest height of \(B\) above the ground is 1.2 m , find the value of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 83, 771, 135]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 153, 918, 219]]<|/det|>
Three particles \(P, Q\) and \(R\), of masses \(0.6 \mathrm{~kg}, 0.4 \mathrm{~kg}\) and \(0.8 \mathrm{~kg}\) respectively, are at rest in a straight line on a smooth horizontal plane. The distance from \(P\) to \(Q\) is \(3 \mathrm{~m}\), and the distance from \(Q\) to \(R\) is also \(3 \mathrm{~m}\) (see diagram). \(P\) is projected directly towards \(Q\) with speed \(3 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\). After \(P\) and \(Q\) collide, \(P\) continues to move in the same direction with speed \(1.5 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 234, 144, 250]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 233, 457, 250]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the speed of \(Q\) after the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 603, 662, 620]]<|/det|>
<pre>In the subsequent collision between \(Q\) and \(R\), these particles coalesce.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 635, 144, 651]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 634, 616, 651]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the speed of the combined particle after this collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the time that it takes from when \(P\) is initially projected until the instant at which \(P\) collides with the combined particle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
6

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 87, 750, 230]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 245, 918, 293]]<|/det|>
A block of mass 12 kg is placed on a rough plane inclined at an angle of \(\alpha\) to the horizontal, where \(\alpha=\tan ^{-1}0.5\). A force of \(X \mathrm{~N}\) is applied to the block, directly up the plane (see diagram). The coefficient of friction between the block and the plane is \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 308, 144, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 307, 452, 325]]<|/det|>
(a) It is given that \(\mu=0.15\) and \(X=20\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 338, 764, 356]]<|/det|>
Find the time that it takes for the block to move 2 m down the plane from rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 77, 144, 93]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 918, 108]]<|/det|>
(b) It is given instead that \(\mu \neq 0.15\) and that when \(X=10\), the block is on the point of moving down the plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 121, 918, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\mu\) and the value of \(X\) for which the block is on the point of moving up the plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 77, 99, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 78, 918, 128]]<|/det|>
7 A particle moves in a straight line. The velocity \(v \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) of the particle \(t \mathrm{~s}\) after leaving a fixed point \(O\) is given by \(v=k\left(20+p t-6 t^{2}\right)\), where \(k\) and \(p\) are constants. The acceleration of the particle at \(t=1\) is \(42 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\), and the displacement of the particle from \(O\) at \(t=1\) is \(93 \mathrm{~m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 144, 144, 160]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 141, 386, 160]]<|/det|>
(a) Show that \(k=3\) and \(p=26\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the distance moved by the particle between the time at which its acceleration is zero and the time at which its velocity is zero.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 72, 567, 88]]<|/det|>
# Additional page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
